unnormalised: Okay, so you're planning an event in India and need help with dates and times, right? It can be a bit tricky with all the festivals and regional variations. A lot of people prepone or postpone events based on auspicious days, according to the Hindu calendar (Panchang). So, first check for major festivals like Diwali (usually falls in Oct/Nov), Holi (March), Eid (date varies based on the Islamic calendar), or Christmas (25/12). These dates are often already booked solid for venues and vendors.

unnormalised: For timings, consider the local culture. Evening events (6:00 PM onwards) are generally preferred for social gatherings. Corporate events might start earlier, say 10:00 AM, but avoid clashing with lunch breaks (1:00 PM to 2:00 PM). If you're targeting an international audience, remember to clearly specify the time zone (IST - Indian Standard Time) when communicating the schedule. Something like "Meeting at 4:00 PM IST" avoids confusion.

unnormalised: Finally, check for local holidays! Republic Day (26/01), Independence Day (15/08), and Gandhi Jayanti (02/10) are national holidays. Also, each state has its own regional holidays. A harvest festival in Kerala (Onam, usually in August/Sept) or a state formation day can affect attendance and availability of resources. So, a little research beforehand will save you a lot of headaches down the line!
